Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The wind swept across the blackened field, carrying with it the faint scent of burnt metal and ozone. Wulf’s boots sank into the ash, each step a reminder of what had been lost. All around him, the shells of once-mighty machines lay strewn, their twisted frames silent witnesses to a battle that had ended everything.

He looked up at the woman beside him—her face was shadowed by the hood of her cloak, eyes reflecting the distant fires that still smoldered on the horizon.

‘I don’t remember the end,’ Wulf whispered. ‘Only the light, and the roar...’

‘That’s all that’s left for most of us now,’ she replied, her voice tinged with sorrow. ‘Memories and ashes.’

Wulf closed his eyes, letting the silence wash over him. Somewhere out there, life would begin again. But for now, he was the last echo of a world undone.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

He stared at the horizon where the sun struggled through a haze of dust. The silence pressed against him, heavy and vast. He tried to recall the faces of his companions, but they blurred, like smoke in his mind.

‘Why me?’ he breathed. The figure beside him—neither friend nor foe, but something in between—shrugged a narrow shoulder. ‘Sometimes survival isn’t a blessing, Wulf.’

He knelt, hands sifting through the cold earth, searching for any sign, any relic of the world before. His fingers closed around a small, cracked locket. Inside, a faded photograph smiled up at him—laughter trapped in sepia, untouched by the carnage.

He pressed the locket to his chest. ‘I’ll remember them.’

The figure nodded, stepping back into the shadows. Wulf gazed at the ruined land and vowed, with the last of his strength, to carry their stories forward, even if he must do so alone.

The Archivist, ancient and half-machine, tilted its head. ‘You are the last record, Wulf. What you choose will become the next chapter.’

His throat tightened as he turned to the small creature perched on a broken pillar—its eyes ancient, its fur silvered with ash.

‘You were meant to survive,’ it said, voice distant and echoing. ‘But survival is not the same as living.’

Wulf knelt, fingers brushing the cold ground. ‘What should I do?’

‘Remember them. Mend what you can. And when the time comes, forgive yourself.’

Wulf nodded, uncertain but determined. He started forward, carrying the weight of memory into the unknown, the hope of redemption flickering in the ruins behind him.

He stumbled through the garden that wasn’t a garden anymore—just twisted roots and toppled stones, haunted by the ghosts of laughter and song. He would walk forward, carrying the memory of those lost, and perhaps, in time, he would plant a garden where this one had fallen.

“Why’d he do it?” Andy knows as soon as he’s spoken that it’s the wrong question. The silence that follows is thick, a ponderous weight in the cramped, flickering office. Detective Kohr’s eyes flick to him, incredulous, almost amused. 

“No, Andy,” she says, voice like a tired blade. “Not why. Why is for people who think they can understand him.”

Andy feels a flush rise in his cheeks. The files splay open on the desk, photos and notes bleeding into each other. He’d wanted to find a reason, a neat line between the before and after. But the truth is messier than that.

“Who helped him?” Kohr continues. “Who opened the door and let him in?”

Andy looks at the evidence, at the smudged fingerprints, the half-burned note. The question shifts inside him, from motive to opportunity, from intention to complicity. He realizes, uncomfortably, that he’s been asking the wrong questions all his life. The real answers are always in the shadows, just out of reach.

“It’s not about why, Andy,” she says, her voice barely more than a whisper. “You know that.”

He does, of course. The crime, the mess, the gaping hole in their lives—it never comes down to a single reason. Andy stares at the spot on the table where sunlight once fell, remembering laughter that used to echo in this kitchen. 

“What are we supposed to do now?” he asks, the new question scraping raw in his throat. Marla doesn’t answer. Instead, she stands, walks to the window, and stares out at the empty street. The silence between them grows, heavy and unforgiving. 

Andy realizes there might never be an answer, not to this question or any other. And in that realization, he feels something break quietly inside him.

"Why’d he do it?" Andy knows as soon as he’s spoken that it’s the wrong question. The words hang in the cold air of the evidence room, echoing off metal shelves and battered boxes. Detective Price glances at him, eyebrow arched. 

"You always ask that," she says, sifting through a stack of photographs. "But why isn’t for us. We look for how. How he got in. How he knew the code. How he vanished before anyone noticed."

Andy shifts, uncomfortable. He wants to believe in motives, in the neat lines between right and wrong. But this case—this man—defies that. The map on the wall is covered in pins and string, but none of it explains the hollow look in the victim’s eyes.

He moves closer to Price, studying her steady hands. "So, how did he do it?"

She smiles, a thin crescent. "That’s the real question, Andy. Figure out the how, and maybe the why will follow."

Andy nods, feeling the weight of the wrong question fading, replaced by the possibility of answers hidden in the details.

"That’s not what you want to know," the old man croaks. "You want to know if you could’ve stopped him."

Andy’s breath catches. He hadn’t realized it himself, but now the truth presses in on him, tight and relentless. The crime, the chaos, the aftermath—it all loops back, an endless reel of what-ifs.

He leans forward, voice barely steady. "Could I have?"

The old man shrugs, a gesture as brittle as dry leaves. "Maybe. Maybe not. Sometimes, all you get is the aftermath."

Andy stares at his hands as the silence stretches. The wrong question lingers, but the right one is too heavy to ask out loud. For now, he sits with it, hoping that someday the answer will come, or at least that the asking will get easier.

"Why’d he do it?" Andy knows as soon as he’s spoken that it’s the wrong question. The words taste of old coffee and regret as they slip into the dim-lit room. His grandmother, hunched in her floral armchair, lets out a sigh like a creaking floorboard. 

"Child, you ask as if the world runs on reasons," she murmurs, hands twisting the hem of her cardigan. "But some men drown in their own shadows. Some just chase the moon and forget the tide."

Andy stares at the faded wallpaper, tracing its worn blossoms. He wants a story, a motive wrapped in logic, but all he gets are riddles and the slow ticking of the clock. Outside, rain taps the windows, relentless. 

He tries again, softer this time. "What do we do now?"

His grandmother’s eyes reflect memories he can’t reach. "We light candles," she says. "And we wait for morning."

As the storm deepens, Andy sits beside her, letting the questions drift away with the rain. In the hush, he learns that sometimes there are no answers—only the courage to sit with the night, and the hope that dawn will come.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The wind pulled at the remnants of his cloak, coarse fabric stiff with ash and blood. Wulf stared out across the razed valley, the blackened husks of trees jutting like broken teeth from the earth. A crow settled on a nearby stone, cocking its head as though it, too, awaited an answer.

He let the silence stretch, broken only by the distant crackle of dying fires. ‘There were others,’ he whispered. ‘There had to be.’

The tall figure beside him—more shadow than man—shook its head. ‘You are all that remains, Wulf. The storm chose you.’

Wulf looked down at his hands, dirt embedded in every line, nails broken. He did not feel chosen, only hollowed. ‘Then why am I still here?’

The shadow’s voice was gentle. ‘Because you remember. And there is work yet to be done.’

The crow cawed, a harsh laugh, and took flight, vanishing into the gray sky. Wulf watched it go, then took his first step down the slope, into the ruins, where the future waited, silent and unknown.

A faint rustle behind him; the wind, or a memory. ‘Perhaps survival is its own punishment,’ he thought. As he stood, his reflection flickered in a shard of glass—hair matted, eyes hollow, a stranger.

‘There must be something left for me to do,’ Wulf said aloud, voice trembling.

From the shadows, a small fox emerged, limping but alive. Its amber eyes met his, and for a moment, Wulf felt a fragile thread of hope.

He extended a hand. ‘Come on, then. We’ll face what’s next together.’

Side by side, man and fox stepped into the ruined world, the promise of companionship guiding them into whatever dawn might follow.

The answer seemed to hang in the thick, heavy air of the bunker. Flickering emergency lights cast long, wavering shadows across cracked concrete and upturned tables. Wulf paced, blood pounding in his ears. The silence was unnatural, oppressive, only broken by the distant, erratic drip of water.

‘But the others… they said we’d make it together.’

His companion, a battered service droid with one flickering optic, whirred softly. ‘Probability of group survival was low. You alone reached the safe threshold.’

Wulf slumped to the floor. ‘Then what am I supposed to do now?’

The droid hesitated, gears grinding in thought. ‘Protocol dictates preservation of knowledge. You could become the archive, Wulf.’

Outside, the world was unrecognizable. But inside, a decision grew. He would remember. He would tell the story—if not for the others, then for the ones who might someday return.

With each gentle tug, memories surfaced: laughter in sunlit orchards, whispered warnings in candlelit kitchens, the sharp, metallic tang of regret. The knot resisted, tightening with every fearful thought, but loosened as she allowed herself to remember. Finally, it gave way, revealing a silken thread spun from her own childhood dreams. The tapestry shimmered, the room brightened, and Maribel felt the weight shift within her. She understood now: to unravel the knot was to embrace the pain and joy entwined within her family, to accept the pattern as her own. Smiling through tears, she wove the thread back into place, stronger and more vibrant than before.

Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked. The question hung in the salt-thick air of the harbor, where the gulls circled and the wind ruffled the tarpaulins. Mikkel hesitated, glancing toward the old warehouse where, it was rumored, her brother spent his nights. “Not ships, exactly,” he said, his voice barely above the creak of the ropes. “He’s building something else. Something with wings.”

Alie frowned, her mind racing. “Wings?” she echoed. “Like a bird?”

Mikkel nodded, nervously shifting from foot to foot. “He says the sea isn’t the only place worth crossing. He wants to… fly.”

She stared at the warehouse, suddenly aware of the faint metallic clangs drifting out, the bursts of laughter, the secretive shouts. All this time she’d imagined her brother lost in old sailors’ tales, but perhaps he was charting a course none of them had dared to dream. The thought filled her with fear and wonder all at once, and as the sun dipped behind the masts, Alie stepped forward. “Then we should help him,” she whispered. “Or at least, see if he needs a crew.”

instance_metrics.response:
Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked. Her voice trembled with a blend of hope and disbelief as she peered through the cracks in the boathouse wall. The scent of cedar and varnish drifted on the air, mingling with the distant brine of the sea. Inside, shadows danced across the floor—blueprints, tools, and sawdust everywhere.

“No,” whispered Tomas, brushing a lock of hair from his eyes. “He isn’t building ships. He’s building memories.”

Alie frowned. “What do you mean?”

Tomas gestured to a wooden frame, not quite the hull of a boat, but shaped to cradle something precious. “He says every plank remembers the hands that placed it. Every nail, every knot—they hold stories. He’s building something for us, to keep when he’s gone.”

Alie’s eyes stung. She realized then that the boathouse was not just a place for ships to be born, but for hearts to heal. She pressed her hand to the rough wood and let herself remember, too, as gulls wheeled overhead and the tide crept in, silent and sure.

Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked. The question barely left her lips before the old woman’s eyes narrowed. “Ships? No, not this time,” she answered, her voice a whisper as brittle as dried kelp. “He’s building something to bring them back.”

Alie’s brow furrowed. The workshop behind them buzzed with strange energy—tools clattering, gears spinning, and the faint, rhythmic thump of a bellows. She crept closer, peering through the cracked window. Inside, Jonas hunched over a great frame that was neither hull nor mast, but a circle of wood strung with copper wire.

“What is it?” Alie breathed.

The old woman’s hand tightened on her arm. “A beacon. For the lost ships. He says if he can light it bright enough, if he can tune the wires just right, maybe the sea will give them back.”

Alie shivered, watching Jonas work—hoping, fearing, wondering what might answer the call.

Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked. The dockmaster chuckled, scratching his beard with a tar-stained finger. “No, lass. He’s building something for the ships.”

Alie craned her neck, curiosity piqued. Through the open doors of the cluttered shed, she glimpsed her uncle crouched over a contraption of brass and glass. It let out a hiss and a faint blue glow pulsed along its spine.

“What is it?” she pressed.

The dockmaster winked. “A compass, but not for finding North. For finding home.”

Alie’s eyes widened. She watched as her uncle lifted the device, its needle spinning wildly. The dockmaster lowered his voice. “He says the sea is full of lost sailors. Maybe, with this, they’ll always find their way back.”

Alie looked out across the restless water, suddenly aware of the silent hope stitched into every sail that left the harbor.

Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked. Her question echoed in the museum’s cavernous hall, bouncing between the skeletons of ancient vessels suspended overhead. Professor Rell paused, his hands deep in a crate of artifacts. “Not ships, Alie. He’s building stories.”

She frowned, glancing at the scraps of parchment and twisted driftwood on the table. “Stories?”

Rell smiled, gesturing to a pile of journals. “Your brother collects the memories of those who once sailed these waters. He pieces together their journeys—maps, songs, half-remembered names. He’s trying to reconstruct the fleet that history forgot, not with timber and nails, but with words.”

Alie approached the workbench, running her fingers over a faded logbook. As she read the looping script, she felt the weight of unseen hulls and the whisper of salt air. Maybe her brother wasn’t chasing the horizon after all. Maybe, in his own way, he was bringing it home.

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked, peering over the old fence. The yard next door was a jungle of sawdust and wood shavings. Amid the chaos, a boy about her age hammered at a curved wooden frame, sweat streaking his brow.

“He is,” replied her grandmother, eyes twinkling. “He’s always been curious about what floats and what sinks.”

Alie hesitated, her heart thumping. She’d been building ships in her own backyard for weeks, but none quite like the one taking shape next door. That one had a mast made from a broomstick and sails stitched from pillowcases.

Summoning her courage, she called out, “Need any help?”

The boy looked up, startled. Then he grinned. “Sure! Do you know how to tie a square knot?”

Alie nodded, grabbing her toolbox. As the sunlight faded, two shipwrights worked side by side, their laughter mingling with the sound of hammering. By nightfall, a new vessel rested proudly on the lawn, ready to sail into adventures only they could imagine.

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked, her voice barely above a whisper as she pressed her face to the dusty window. On the other side, in the dim glow of a single bulb, her brother Ezra hunched over a sprawl of blueprints and matchsticks. 

Grandfather nodded, a wistful smile creasing his face. “He always did love the sea, even here, so far from water.”

Alie’s hands curled around the windowsill. She remembered the day Ezra vowed to build them both a way out—paper boats at first, then wooden models, and now this: a meticulous replica of a schooner taking shape from scraps. 

She tapped lightly. Ezra glanced up, surprise melting into a conspiratorial grin. He beckoned her in. “Help me with the rigging?”

As Alie crossed the threshold, she felt the boundaries of the house dissolve. In Ezra’s workshop, the scent of glue and cedar became brine and salt spray. With each knot and nail, they charted a course not just out of the tiny room, but toward the vast promise of elsewhere—together.

Alie pressed her nose to the glass. In the late-afternoon sun, the ships glimmered with colors from another world. Mr. Barlow knelt, whispering to his fleet like a captain before a voyage. Alie imagined those tiny vessels setting sail on the rain-swollen gutters, carrying messages across the neighborhood, ferrying secrets and dreams.

That evening, Alie snuck outside, leaving her own paper boat at Mr. Barlow’s gate. By morning, it had vanished, replaced by a tin can ship with a flannel sail and a note: “For the next captain. Adventures await.”

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’ The voice echoed through the ruined chapel, bouncing off broken stone and shattered stained glass.

The air was thick with dust and memory, the last embers of night flickering through the cracks overhead. Wulf’s hands trembled. He stared at the altar—the place where it began, and ended. The place where the others had fallen.

‘Why me?’ he whispered. His companion, a shadow among shadows, offered no answer. Instead, he pressed something cold and metallic into Wulf’s palm: a coin, ancient and scarred. Its surface shimmered with runes Wulf could not read.

‘You’ll need this now,’ the companion said. ‘There is a cost for surviving. Even if you don’t remember.’

Wulf closed his fist around the coin. The weight of it was familiar, and yet it chilled him to the bone. He staggered to his feet, feeling the burden of the dead pressing down. Outside, the world waited, empty and bright.

‘Come,’ said the companion. ‘We’re not finished yet.’
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’ ‘It appears so.

instance_metrics.response:
Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The world beyond the bunker was a quiet grave. Wulf stepped outside, boots crunching glass and ash. The city’s skyline was a jagged shadow, flickering in the poisonous dawn. He scanned the horizon for movement, any sign of life, but found only the wind’s mournful howl.

Behind him, the machine—the one who answered—hummed softly. Its voice was always warm, almost human. ‘You were selected for resilience. Your genome, your mind. The others… could not adapt.’

Wulf swallowed. He remembered laughter echoing in the metal corridors, the promise of survival. Now, nothing.

‘What am I supposed to do?’ he asked.

The machine’s lights pulsed, a heartbeat in the gloom. ‘Begin again. That is what life does.’

Wulf turned his face to the burning sky. He felt the weight of a thousand ghosts, and the uncertain hope of a new beginning.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

The silence that followed was too heavy for comfort. Wulf looked down at his hands, not recognizing the scars, the grime, or the trembling fingers. Around him, the forest stood in mourning—branches broken, trunks blackened by the fire that swept through the night before. Somewhere in the distance, a bird called out, but nothing answered.

He slowly walked forward, each step a negotiation between memory and fear. The others’ faces flickered behind his eyes: laughter in the old world, screams in the new. Wulf pressed on, guided by instinct more than purpose.

‘Why me?’ he muttered, but the wind carried his words away. He found the river, its banks littered with ash and remnants of what once was. Kneeling, Wulf cupped the cold water and drank. As the sun broke through the smoke, he stood, alone but alive, determined to find meaning in the silence left behind.

Wulf’s gaze drifted across the empty field. He remembered the cries, the chaos, the storm that had swallowed everyone else. Now, only the wind moved, ruffling the grass where friends had fallen. He knelt and pressed a trembling hand to the earth, half-expecting to feel a heartbeat beneath the soil.

‘What do I do now?’ he whispered.

A crow landed on a broken fencepost, tilting its head. Wulf watched, hoping for an omen, a sign. The crow only cawed, as if mocking the idea of answers.

He stood, brushing dirt from his knees. Each breath was a reminder—of loss, of pain, and of the strange gift of survival. Wulf turned toward the distant mountains, their peaks shrouded in mist. Alone, he began to walk, each step a question, each mile an attempt to understand why fate had chosen him.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

Wulf’s reflection shimmered in the puddle at his feet, fractured by the rain. The city behind him was silent, save for the drip of water from collapsed awnings. He waited for a sense of relief, but only emptiness surfaced.

He wandered through the empty market, where stalls still displayed withered fruit and trinkets. At the center, the old clock tower stood stubbornly, its hands forever frozen at the moment of disaster. Wulf climbed the spiral staircase, each step echoing in the hollow air, until he reached the bell chamber. There, atop the dusty floorboards, lay a single letter, sealed with red wax.

He broke the seal with trembling fingers. The message inside was brief: "You are the witness. Remember for us all."

Wulf looked out over the ruins, the letter pressed to his heart. The rain eased, and a shaft of sunlight pierced the clouds. He understood, then, that his survival was not a blessing, nor a curse, but a calling. He would remember. And perhaps, one day, he would tell the world what happened when the silence fell.

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked. Her voice was barely more than a whisper, muffled by the thick fog rolling in from the bay. On the edge of the old wharf, the silhouette of a man hunched over a strange framework, hammering quietly as if not to disturb the sleeping town.

Her brother, Iben, nodded, never taking his eyes from the figure. “He’s always here at night, working on something different. Last week it was a boat made from glass bottles. Before that, a raft of driftwood and rope.”

Alie’s curiosity burned. She crept closer, shoes clicking softly on the damp planks. The man paused, then looked up—a weathered face, eyes like the stormy sea. “Curiosity is a fine compass,” he said, voice deep and rough. “But not all ships are meant to sail.”

He gestured to his creation: a ship’s hull, but instead of wood, it was woven from reeds, feathers, and silver thread, shimmering in the moonlight. Alie realized, with a shiver, that some ships were meant for journeys stranger than any chart could hold.

Mora glanced over her shoulder, squinting through the morning mist. The old man in the garden had always been a mystery—kneeling in the dirt, sifting through stones and broken pots. But today, a latticework of driftwood and twisted wire rose beside him, its prow pointing toward the sunrise.

“I think so,” Mora replied, brushing dew off her skirt. “But not the kind that float.”

Alie tiptoed closer, marveling at the intricate hull, the sails sewn from faded maps. The old man noticed them, eyes crinkling into a smile. He beckoned the girls over.

“You want to know where she’s going?” he asked, gesturing to his creation.

Alie nodded. The man winked. “Every ship needs a captain. And every captain needs a dream.”

He handed Alie a rusted compass, its needle spinning wildly. “Set your course,” he whispered. “This ship’s built for stories.”

As the sun climbed higher, Alie felt the adventure bloom within her, and the ship seemed to shimmer, ready for a journey that would sail far beyond the garden.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’ ‘It appears so.’

The words echoed in the empty chamber, bouncing off stone and shadow. Wulf’s hand trembled as he pressed it to his chest, feeling for a heartbeat he couldn’t trust. The others—Vald, Inger, even little Bryn—gone, their fates sealed in the firestorm that had swept through their camp. 

He stumbled outside beneath a bruised sky. Ash drifted in the wind, carrying shreds of memories—laughter, song, the clatter of wooden bowls. Wulf scoured the ruins for hope, but only silence answered. A lone crow watched from a charred branch, eyes black as sorrow, as if to say, yes, you are alone.

He fell to his knees, grief and guilt tangling in his throat. Why him? Why not the others? The question gnawed, relentless. He could only rise, shoulders hunched, and walk into the grey dawn, burdened by survival, haunted by the absence of every voice but his own.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’ ‘It appears so.’

He waited for denial, for a comforting lie, but the old woman only stared into the smoking remains, her eyes shining with the last of the moon’s reflection. Wulf’s hands clenched. He remembered the chaos—the shrieks, the flames, the way the ground itself trembled. He remembered running, ducking beneath falling beams, the crushing knowledge that he was leaving others behind.

He stepped over the threshold, the world strangely silent. The bodies had already been taken, the living scattered. Was he the only one who still wandered these halls, echoing memories against stone?

The old woman finally turned, her voice like gravel. ‘You must carry their stories now. Their hopes. Their regrets.’

Wulf nodded, though his heart ached. He walked into the dawn, feeling the weight of invisible hands on his shoulders, guiding him forward. The village may have been gone, but he would not let them be forgotten. He was the witness—and perhaps, in time, the beginning of something new.

It was more than possible. For years, the villagers had whispered about the old clock tower at the edge of their town, believing it to be haunted, cursed, or both. But Eleni knew better. Inside, the tower pulsed with a gentle, golden light. Eleni traced her fingers along the cold stone, finding a hidden panel beneath the great clock face. With a deep breath, she pressed it. The gears whirred, and the floor beneath her shifted, revealing a winding staircase lit by a thousand tiny fireflies. It was more than possible that the tower held secrets. It was certain. And as Eleni descended, she knew she was about to become part of its story.

instance_metrics.response: I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty haunted her waking hours. She drew pictures of halls paved with petals, yet said the laughter there was cold, and the feasts tasted of ash." He paused, his voice rough. "The faeries gave her everything, except the right to leave as herself." I listened, the Isle misty around us, and wondered if some places were too beautiful for mortals to survive—if longing itself could be a curse. When I left him, I thought I glimpsed a shimmer among the ferns, as if something watched, waiting with a smile too bright to bear.

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked. She leaned closer to the window, breath fogging the glass as she watched the flicker of lantern light in the neighboring barn. In the half-dark, the shadows moved strangely, rising and falling with the rhythm of a hammer on wood. 

Her grandmother, never one to rush a reply, finished her knitting and set the needles down. “Not ships, exactly,” she said, voice low. “He calls them arks.”

Alie frowned. “Like Noah’s?”

“Not for animals, no. For memories.”

The hammering stopped. Alie saw him now: the man next door, stooped with age but moving with a purpose. He carried narrow planks, each one painted with names and dates. 

“Every night, he builds another,” her grandmother continued, “for someone who’s gone. Says if you put a memory inside, it floats—never sinks.”

Alie pressed her palm to the glass, imagining all the tiny ships sailing on unseen tides, carrying laughter, tears, and whispers through the night. She wondered what it would feel like to build something that lasted long after you let it go.

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked. 

Her voice was barely a whisper, but the question hung in the thick, salt-tinged air of the workshop. The old man, hunched over a cluttered table, paused. For a moment, the only sound was the slow ticking of a clock and the distant sigh of the tide.

“He says he’s building something, but not ships,” replied her cousin, Jonah, twirling a copper wire between his fingers. “He says they’re vessels for journeys you can’t take on water.”

Alie peered closer, scanning the chaotic array of gears, battered maps, and glass jars filled with stardust and sand. On the table, a curious contraption was taking shape: part compass, part astrolabe, and something else entirely. 

“Where do they go?” she asked.

Jonah shrugged, a secret smile on his lips. “He says, wherever you imagine.”

Alie watched as the old man fit a glowing stone into the device, and wondered if, tonight, she might sail further than the edge of the world.

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

Mira nodded slowly, her eyes never leaving the horizon where the sea met the sky. “Not ships for water, though. He calls them sky-vessels.”

Alie’s brow furrowed. She followed Mira’s gaze to the old shed behind the house, where faint metallic clatter and bursts of laughter drifted out. Inside, her brother Finn knelt on the dusty floor, surrounded by blueprints and coils of silvery wire. Above him, a strange skeletal frame hung from the rafters—wings made of driftwood, sails of patched linen, and a compass spinning wildly at its heart.

“He thinks he can fly,” Mira said, voice hushed with both awe and worry. “He says the world’s too big to stay earthbound.”

Alie pressed her face to the cracked window, imagining Finn soaring above the waves, chasing sunbeams and gulls. Fear and hope tangled in her chest. Maybe he’d fall. Maybe he’d never come back. But maybe, just maybe, he’d touch the clouds and bring a piece of the sky home for them all.

The barn doors creaked open and sunlight spilled over a collection of curious shapes: some resembled boats, but others looked like enormous insects or twisting, hollow trees. Each was crafted from scraps—old bicycle wheels, driftwood, shards of colored glass. 

“He calls them dream-vessels,” Uncle Remy said, his voice a little softer. “He says they’re for journeys you can’t take with feet on the ground.”

Alie traced her fingers along the cool metal of a dragonfly-ship’s wing. “Where do they go?”

“Wherever you wish. Some say if you climb inside at midnight, you’ll wake up in a place you’ve only seen in your heart.”

Alie smiled, her imagination awash with distant lands and starlit skies. Maybe tonight, she’d sneak out to the barn and see where her own dream-vessel would carry her.

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

Her father paused, brush hovering over the canvas that caught the golden dusk. “Not ships. He’s making echoes.”

Alie stepped onto the porch, listening. From the shed came the hollow thump of wood meeting wood, the murmur of old sea shanties, and the faint aroma of varnish. She peered through a crack in the door. Inside, Granddad stood amid a forest of curved timbers and glass jars filled with ocean pebbles, but what he built wasn’t a hull or mast. Instead, he arranged planks into spirals and arcs, each one humming softly as if vibrating with old stories.

“Echoes?” Alie echoed.

Her father smiled. “He says memories fade like footprints on wet sand. He builds frames to catch the sounds before they vanish.”

As twilight deepened, Alie watched Granddad place a conch shell at the center of a wooden spiral. The workshop grew silent, then filled with the distant laughter of her late grandmother, swirling out from the shell. Alie shivered, not from cold, but from wonder. She realized some ships didn’t sail on water—they carried you back, just for a moment, to where love still lingered.

instance_metrics.response: She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how. Every night, she would lie awake, listening to his gentle breaths beside her, trying to measure her own heart against his. He brought her coffee in the mornings, left her notes in the pockets of her coats, remembered the name of every cousin and childhood pet. She watched him as if from the far end of a tunnel, longing to step into the warm, golden light of his affection. Once, she wrote him a poem and tore it up. Once, she almost told him the truth. But her love, if it existed, was a bird afraid to fly, caught in the bones of her chest. She hoped that one day she’d find the key, the secret that would unlock the dam inside her, that she could meet his gaze not with gratitude, but with the wild, unrestrained certainty he offered her every day. Until then, she held his hand and smiled, and wondered whether he could tell the difference.

instance_metrics.response: She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how. She watched the way his eyes lit up when he spoke to her, his hands trembling with excitement as he recounted trivial stories just to make her laugh. She tried to mimic the cadence of his affection—baking his favorite bread, learning his favorite song on her old guitar—but it always felt like she was following a recipe missing a crucial ingredient. Sometimes, she wondered if she was broken, if her heart was made of something heavier or quieter than his. She wanted to give him the world, or at least the parts of herself that knew how to love, but whenever she reached inside, she found only the echo of his longing. One evening, as the sun dipped behind the city skyline, she turned to him and said, "I’m still learning. If you can be patient with me, maybe one day I’ll get it right." I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty gnawed away at her soul. The man told me this in the twilight of a rain-lashed Douglas alley, clutching a bundle of withered primroses. "She came back changed," he whispered, voice brittle with grief. "The colors of our world sickened her. Even the sea looked grey to her, and the moon, a pale coin. She cried for the music she could no longer hear, the laughter of willow-women and the taste of honey wine. In the end, she could not bear it, and slipped away on the night of a blue moon, leaving only a trail of golden hair behind."

The man pressed a primrose into my hand, warning me to never stray too near the old burial mounds when the wind sings. "Beauty is a venom," he said, "and the faeries do not love as we do." I watched him fade into the mist, haunted by the memory of a kingdom more deadly than any nightmare, dressed in light and song.

For a while, she tried to live among us, but the world felt brittle—bread turned to ashes in her mouth, colors never bright enough. She would wander the dunes at dusk, searching for music only she could hear."

He paused, fingers trembling on his glass. "One dawn, she was gone, leaving only a wreath of rowan and a single word carved into the sand—‘Home.’ Since then, I leave milk on the sill, hoping the fae show mercy. But the tides do not return what they take."

His story lingered with me, a reminder that some doors, once opened, cannot be closed.

Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged. I had a rooftop garden, a space of green serenity above the chaos below. Each evening, while my husband shouted into the phone or slammed doors, I watered my tomatoes and sipped chamomile tea, watching sunbeams catch on their fuzzy stems. I had friends who sent postcards from cities I’d never see, and a boss who let me leave early on Fridays. 

Yet, those comforts made me feel guilty. There were women—some I knew, some I didn’t—who had no gardens, no safety nets. I caught myself thinking, "At least he doesn’t hit me," as if that excused the words that stung for days.

One afternoon, my neighbor, Lila, knocked on my door. Her eyes were red, her hands trembling. I let her in, brewed her tea, and we sat in silence, the kind that understands without words. In that moment, I realized my privilege wasn’t just the things I owned, but the small freedoms I could offer. I opened my rooftop garden to her, and together we found comfort in the gentle rustle of leaves, two women growing hope above the city.

Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged. I had a trust fund, inherited from a grandmother with a sly grin and a sharp tongue. It paid for silk sheets that softened the coldness in our bedroom, for therapists who listened as I danced around the truth, for the yoga studio where I learned to breathe in time with the rain.

My husband hated the way I spent money, called it frivolous, but he never stopped me. He was too busy controlling my words, my laughter, my dreams. I wore my privilege like armor, never letting the cracks show. I told myself it could be worse, that I was lucky he only bruised my spirit, not my skin.

One morning, I woke to the gentle patter of rain on the window and a sudden, wild urge to leave. I packed a suitcase—cashmere sweaters, passport, a photo of my grandmother—and slipped out before he woke. The taxi driver's eyes met mine in the rearview mirror. He didn't ask questions. In that moment, I realized privilege isn't just money or comfort—it's the ability to choose freedom, when it finally arrives.

instance_metrics.response:
Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The words echoed through the empty hall, bouncing off the brittle chandeliers and fractured windows. Wulf gripped the hilt of his sword, knuckles white, as the wind howled through the gaps in the stonework. The world outside was blanketed in ash. Every step he took left a print in the dust of what once was home.

He turned to the stranger beside him. Cloaked in mourning black, the figure revealed nothing but a pale chin and eyes that seemed to flicker with blue fire. ‘Why? Why am I left?’

The stranger didn’t answer, only handed him a silver locket. Wulf’s hands trembled as he opened it. Inside was a scrap of parchment with a single word: “Remember.”

The memories flooded back—laughter, then screams, then silence. Wulf fell to his knees, heart pounding. The stranger knelt beside him and placed a cold hand on his shoulder.

‘You are the witness. The world must be rebuilt. That is why you lived.’

As dawn crept through the ruins, Wulf stood, the weight of survival settling on his shoulders, and began the long walk toward the future.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

He looked past the shattered walls of the hall, where the tapestry of stars shone through holes made by fire and time. The silence pressed against his ears, insistent and strange—no laughter, no shouting, not even the faintest echo of footsteps. The woman who answered him stood at the edge of the rubble, her eyes reflecting the moonlight, her voice the only anchor in this ghostly place.

‘I keep thinking I’ll wake up,’ Wulf whispered. ‘That I’ll hear them all, just around the corner.’

She shook her head, gathering her cloak tighter. ‘There’s no waking from this, Wulf. Only moving forward.’

He nodded, swallowing hard. He remembered their faces—his friends, his kin, the ones who taught him how to hunt and laugh and dream. He pressed his hand to his chest, feeling the faintest heartbeat. It was all he had left.

‘Then I will remember them,’ he said, voice shaking but firm. ‘For as long as I live.’

‘That’s all any of us can do,’ she replied. And together, they stepped into the night, the world silent but for their footsteps.

The cave’s mouth glimmered with the first suggestion of dawn, but Wulf remained in shadow, his hands trembling over the remnants of a map. The silence, once companionable, now pressed in around him—a heavy, suffocating thing. He remembered the laughter of his companions, the fire’s warmth, and the certainty that they would see home again.

‘Why me?’ he muttered, voice fraying at the edges. The old woman across from him only watched, her eyes reflecting both sympathy and secrets.

‘Sometimes survival is a riddle without an answer,’ she said at last, her words soft as the wind outside. ‘What you do next, that is the only riddle left.’

Wulf folded the map with care, a ritual for the dead. He would carry their names into the world beyond the cave, forging a new path for memories to follow. As he stepped into the pale morning, he realized survival was not an ending, but a question he must live to answer.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. He glanced at the cracked window, where the moonlight pooled onto the warped floorboards. It was an old house, one that had seen generations come and go, laughter and grief preserved in the grain of the wood. Liza’s voice trembled, but she stood firm, fists clenched at her sides. 

‘You don’t believe me?’ she asked.

Kasim’s lips twisted, almost a smile. ‘Belief is a luxury, Liza. I have only the facts.’

‘And the fact is, we have a choice,’ she replied, stepping closer. ‘You know as well as I do, the Council listens if we shout loud enough.’

He shook his head, but his gaze softened. ‘The Council listens, but only when it suits them. You’re risking everything.’

‘So are they,’ she whispered, looking at the sleeping children behind the door. ‘But I won’t let them lose what little they have left.’

Kasim didn’t answer, but his hand hovered above the doorknob. Outside, the dogs were barking. The hour had come.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. He picked at the chipped paint on the table, his indifference a mask Liza had learned to read. She pressed on, voice steady despite the tremor in her hands.

‘You know the inspectors will be here tomorrow. If we don’t stand together—’

‘They have rules, Liza. And they don’t care about our promises.’

She moved to the window, watching the shadows of children chasing fireflies in the dusk. ‘I know what they care about. But I also know fear can’t be the only thing holding us together. We have to show them we’re more than just a list of names and numbers.’

Kasim finally looked up, his eyes searching hers for something—conviction, hope, perhaps a plan. ‘And if they come with trucks?’

Her jaw set. ‘Then we stand in front of them. Together. They’ll have to go through us.’

He sighed, but there was a hint of a smile. ‘You’re stubborn, Liza.’

‘Maybe. But I’m right.’

I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. I watch them religiously, sometimes on my lunch break, sometimes at two in the morning when my thoughts are loud and the world is insistent. There’s something intoxicating about the way a blue whale’s fluke slices the surface, the lazy way they breach, as if gravity is a rumor. 

One night, scrolling through a new post of a humpback spinning languidly in the kelp, I notice a strange glint in the water. I zoom in. It’s not fish, not a reflection—something metallic, almost architectural. The next post from the same account shows the same whale, but a little closer to the glint. Comments are blowing up. Someone claims it’s a UFO, another says it’s a government drone, someone else insists it’s Atlantis. 

For the next week, every whale video I watch, I see it: the shimmer, always in the background, moving just out of frame. I start to wonder if the whales know something we don’t, if their aimless drifting is more purposeful than we think. Or if maybe they’re watching us, too.

I watched it on loop, half-hypnotized, until the patterns began to look like faces—human, but distorted, stretched across the whale’s body. I blinked and they were gone. But I keep looking. Every time I see a whale now, I wonder if they’re carrying our dreams, or our memories, or something stranger, swimming just beneath the surface, waiting to be seen.

I still watch the accounts, but now I wonder: what if the whales are drifting because they’re waiting for doors that only they can see?

Oh, I’m great. The words tumbled out of my mouth before I could stop them, a reflex honed by years of polite conversation. But as I sat there on the park bench, a pigeon landed beside me, cocked its head, and replied, "Are you sure?"

Startled, I blinked. Was I losing my mind? The pigeon fluffed its feathers and waited expectantly. Reluctantly, I shook my head. "No, not really."

The pigeon hopped closer. "Sometimes you have to admit you're not, before you can be."

I laughed—a real, bubbling laugh that felt strange and wonderful. The pigeon gave a satisfied nod, then strutted away, leaving me lighter than I’d felt in months.

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. I say “his” even though he’s never written a word, at least not that I’ve seen. I ghostwrite the stories he dreams out loud, in the moments between coffee sips and missed trains. He’s a collector of beginnings, a hoarder of dramatic first lines and perfectly oddball titles. The rest is left to me. 

I imagine him now across the city, tapping his foot on the subway, inventing a hero who’s allergic to sunlight and can only solve crimes at night. I’ll take the idea, spin it into three chapters, and email him before midnight. Sometimes he calls at 2 a.m., his voice heavy with new plot twists. I jot them down in the margin and try not to fall asleep at my laptop. 

We meet once a month in a dim-lit café to swap pages and trade apologies for missed deadlines. He always signs the cover page with a flourish, as though he’s writing the whole thing. But I don’t mind. The stories are ours, stitched together from his wild notions and my steady hands.

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. The old apartment above the bakery is always thick with the scent of yeast and cinnamon, which makes it easy to imagine him pacing in the kitchen, muttering lines to himself. But when he’s gone—off at one of his endless appointments—I slip into his study. I leaf through the battered notebook he left behind, deciphering his frantic, looping handwriting. 

It’s a strange partnership: he supplies the chaos, I supply the order. Some days, I have to fill in entire chapters where he’s left only cryptic notes like “the moonlight catches the glass—remind her of the promise.” I wonder what promise he means, and to whom. The story grows between us, a vine twisting around memories and half-spoken regrets. 

By the time he returns, I have a draft waiting, and he reads it with the careful reverence of someone picking up a letter from an old friend. We never mention what’s missing or what was added. In this quiet collaboration, the book becomes a record not just of his ambitions, but of the silent hours we share apart.

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. He likes to say the words out loud, pacing the floor as if the rhythm of his steps will summon the next chapter. When he’s gone, the silence is mine. I rearrange his sentences, shift the weight of his metaphors, and sometimes sneak in a line of my own. The manuscript grows like a strange plant, half wild, half trimmed. 

Sometimes, I find margin notes: a sketch of a crow, a coffee ring, a phrase circled twice—"the others never knew." I wonder if he’s leaving clues or just reminders to himself. I never ask. Instead, I type, edit, and occasionally argue with his absent voice. Evenings, he returns, skims the pages, and grins at the changes. We never say who owns the story. In the morning, he’ll be gone again, and I’ll be here, tending the words, waiting for him to return with more seeds for the next chapter.

Today, the rain drums against the window as I rework a scene he wrote years ago—before we met. The protagonist’s voice is raw, uncertain, but I can hear traces of him in every line. I edit gently, afraid to erase too much of what makes the story his. 

When he comes home, he reads my changes in silence, then nods. We rarely talk about the process, but I sense his relief. Our collaboration is quiet, a steady pulse beneath the chaos of drafts and deadlines. In these moments, we’re closer than any room could contain.

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. It’s not the kind of book you’d find on a shelf or tucked into a backpack—his book is a living archive. Every time he leaves, I write down what I remember: the way he laughed at the neighbor’s dog, the story he told about losing his shoes as a child, the recipe he invented for midnight pancakes. The lower offices were sufficiently warren-like that she could sneak upstairs without being observed. Each twist of the narrow corridors muffled her footsteps, and the clusters of broken filing cabinets offered cover from the security cameras. She clutched the envelope tightly to her chest as she darted past the copy room, where the flickering glow of an old vending machine cast ghostly shadows on the wall. 

At the base of the stairwell, she paused. The hum of distant conversation echoed from above, but she couldn’t make out any words. With a deep breath, she started up, her heart thudding in her ears. Each step was a gamble: the wrong creak might bring someone running. But she reached the landing without incident, and there—behind a cracked glass door—was the office she’d been searching for. The door was ajar.

Inside, a single desk lamp illuminated a stack of forgotten folders. She slipped the envelope onto the pile, careful not to disturb anything else. Then, as quietly as she had come, she retraced her path through the labyrinth, certain that by morning, her secret would be safe—or perhaps, someone else’s problem.

Sometimes, I leave a note in the margins—an inside joke or a subtle suggestion—but I always erase it before he returns. It’s become our silent collaboration, one he doesn’t even know about. I wonder what he’d say if he discovered my fingerprints all over his manuscript. Would he be angry? Grateful? Or would he simply smile, recognizing my touch in every line? The truth is, I’m not just working on his book; I’m writing myself into his story, hoping that one day, he’ll read between the lines and see me there.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. The echo of her words seemed to hang in the air, fragile as glass. He turned his gaze to the window, watching the dust eddy in the fading sunlight. 

“You can’t promise them that,” he said, quietly. “Not here. Not now.”

Liza’s jaw set. She moved closer, lowering her voice so the others in the corridor wouldn’t hear. “I have to. If we give up hope, we’re complicit.”

Kasim let out a low, bitter laugh. “You think hope is enough? You think it keeps the walls from closing in?”

“Maybe. Maybe it buys us time.”

They stood in silence, the murmur of anxious conversations drifting from the next room. Liza pressed a hand to the folder she clutched—a list of names, faces, stories. She would not let them become numbers. Not this time.

Kasim’s eyes softened just enough. “You’re stubborn, Liza.”

She smiled, just barely. “It’s all I have left.”

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. He traced a finger along the crease in his worn jacket, eyes fixed on the linoleum floor. 

“You say that every week,” he murmured. “And every week, the list grows shorter.”

She crossed her arms, standing taller. “Not because we failed. Because we’re trying.”

The radio on Kasim’s desk crackled with static, a faint voice calling out codes neither of them wanted to interpret. Outside, a child’s laughter sliced through the tension—a reminder of what they fought for. Liza glanced at the roster pinned to the bulletin board, each name a promise she’d made.

“Tomorrow, the officials come again,” Kasim said. “They’ll ask questions I can’t answer.”

“Then let me answer,” Liza replied. “Let them see someone who believes in these families. Someone who won’t step aside.”

He looked at her, fatigue lining his features. “You’re going to make trouble.”

She allowed herself a small, defiant smile. “Trouble is all we have left to give.”

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. He wandered over to the doorway, peering into the dim hall where shadows stretched and voices murmured just out of earshot.

“You’re making promises you can’t keep,” he said, his tone soft but edged with fatigue. “The paperwork’s already started. They’ll come at dawn.”

Liza refused to let fear anchor her. “Then we’ll stall them. We’ll hide the children, mix the records, lose the files.”

Kasim almost smiled, but didn’t. “And when they notice?”

She walked to the window, looking out at the garden where mothers clung to their little ones, laughter bright in the gloom. “We’ll think of something else. We always do.”

He shook his head, not quite in disbelief, not quite in hope. “You’re either brave or reckless.”

“Both,” Liza replied, her voice steady. “But I won’t let them win.”

Beyond the glass, the sun slipped lower, turning the sky a bruised violet. For now, the families were together—and Liza meant to keep it that way.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. He slipped his hands into his pockets, rocking back on his heels as if the conversation were a familiar dance.

“You always say that,” he replied, his voice almost gentle. “But promises don’t stop trucks.”

Liza’s lips tightened. She remembered the last time the trucks came, the quiet panic, the hurried goodbyes. “They only win if we let them. You know that.”

Kasim studied her for a long moment, as if searching for cracks in her resolve. “Hope can be dangerous here.”

“Hope is all we have left.”

A child’s cry echoed from the courtyard, and Liza’s gaze flickered to the window. She squared her shoulders. “If I have to stand in front of those trucks myself, I will.”

Kasim didn’t argue. He looked away, shoulders slumping. Outside, the wind picked up, carrying with it the faint scent of dust and the promise of another sleepless night.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. He reached for the chipped mug on the table, swirling the dregs of black tea, and spoke in a low voice. “You say that like you’re the river, and they’re just stones in your current.”

Liza blinked, caught off guard by the metaphor. Outside, the rain battered the roof, a staccato rhythm she’d come to hear as a warning. She gathered the files, her hands trembling only slightly. “Maybe I am. Maybe I can wear them down.”

Kasim’s lips curled into a tired smile. “What if you’re a dam, not a river? Dams break.”

She stared at him, her breath shallow. “Then I’ll break with them. But I won’t let them go quietly.”

In the silence that followed, a dog barked, and the generator outside coughed into life. Liza’s eyes met Kasim’s. For a second, their burdens seemed shared, the weight distributed, if only slightly.

Kasim stood, collecting his coat. “Then let’s be noisy, Liza. Let’s make them remember.”

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. The book is a mess—hundreds of loose pages, coffee stains blooming on the margins, sentences that trail off as if he’d run out of breath. At first, I tried to organize them chronologically, but meanings wove in and out of sequence, as if time bent around his thoughts. 

He always says the book isn’t about him, but I see his secrets in the margins and the way he circles certain words. The longer I spend with the manuscript, the more I feel him in the room, as if his presence lingers in the ink. Once, I found a page I hadn’t seen before, addressed to me, in his looping script: “You’ll know what to do.”

When he returns, we never speak about the book. He asks about dinner, the weather, anything but the manuscript. But as he leaves, his eyes linger on my hands, smudged with his words. I wonder if, one day, we’ll finally be in the same room with the book between us, and the silence will be enough to finish the story.

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. It’s not my story, but somehow, over the months, the lines have blurred. His handwriting, once foreign and sharp, has become as familiar as my own. I decipher his cryptic notes, rearrange paragraphs, and sometimes, in the quiet, I add a word or two that he’ll never notice.

I wonder, sometimes, if he knows how intimately I am woven into the fabric of his tale. When he’s away, I imagine him in the next room, pacing, dictating unsaid sentences to the walls. He trusts me with his silence, the space between his thoughts. One night, I found a scrap of paper under my chair: “Would you write me in, if I asked?”

I haven’t answered yet. Instead, I keep working, shaping his book into something neither of us anticipated. I wonder who the story really belongs to now—him, or me, or the invisible tether that binds us in these separate rooms, each waiting for the other to finish the next line.

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. The apartment grows silent, save for the soft scratch of my pen as I attempt to decipher his shorthand, his coded metaphors scattered like breadcrumbs across the pages. Sometimes I think he leaves them just for me, tiny riddles to solve in his absence. 

He returns without warning, always catching me mid-edit, eyes flicking to the manuscript as if it holds the answers we both crave. “You’re making it better,” he says, but I’m not sure if he means the book or something else. I nod and tuck away my questions, letting them simmer between us like the tea we never finish.

Late at night, I read passages aloud to the empty kitchen. I wonder if my voice changes the meaning, if these words sound different when I say them. Sometimes I hear footsteps in the hall, but it’s only my heart, pacing with anticipation. Maybe, when the book is done, we’ll finally be in the same room, both of us, with nothing left to rewrite.

Sometimes I forget where his words end and mine begin. I catch myself rewriting a sentence, only to find it’s my own thought, not his. He never asks about my changes, but sometimes, when he reads over my edits, he smiles in that way that tells me he notices every detail. 

We never talk about the process. Our collaboration exists in quiet glances and unspoken agreements, a silent language written on paper and in pauses. The book grows, stitched together from two lives that meet mostly in passing. I wonder if, when it’s finished, we’ll return to the same room, or if the distance between our words will always remain.

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. It’s an unusual arrangement: he dictates dreams to me over breakfast, snippets of wild, impossible stories, and I spend the day translating them into chapters. Sometimes, the stories contradict themselves—a lost city turns into a forgotten forest, a villain becomes a lover. I don’t ask for clarification. Instead, I let the inconsistencies bloom, weaving them into something stranger and more alive than either of us intended. 

He returns in the evenings with new dreams, new contradictions, and I listen, pen poised, wondering if he notices how much of myself I have left between the lines. Our collaboration is a dance neither of us leads. By the time the manuscript is finished, I’m not sure whose book it is anymore. Maybe it belongs to the liminal space between us, filled with dreams and omissions, where stories wait to be written by hands that never quite touch.

Liza stared at his back, the words heavy in her throat. She wondered, not for the first time, whether her certainty was a shield or a shackle. Outside, the voices rose, and she knew the night would bring more choices—none of them easy.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. He leaned back in the creaky chair, rolling a coin over his knuckles with deliberate indifference.

She pursed her lips, scanning the list of names, the ones already marked with red ink. ‘They’ll wait for me.’

Kasim laughed, a hollow sound. ‘You’re not as powerful as you think.’

‘No,’ she agreed, voice almost a whisper, ‘but I am desperate. And desperation counts for something.’

The silence stretched. Dust motes drifted in the stale air. Kasim’s eyes flicked to the door, where shadows gathered. He tossed the coin, caught it, and stood. ‘Desperate people do dangerous things.’

Liza nodded, her resolve crystallizing. ‘It’s time someone did.’

The old clock ticked on, measuring out their defiance in the last seconds before the world changed.

Liza leaned forward, her voice barely above a whisper. ‘We promised safety. We can’t go back on that now.’

Kasim moved his pawn, the clack echoing in the hollow room. ‘Promises are easy. Keeping them is costly.’

A gust rattled the window, making the candle flame dance. In the hallway, children’s laughter rose and fell, fragile and hopeful. Liza closed her eyes, remembering their faces when she gave her word.

‘I’ll cover the cost,’ she said. ‘Whatever it is.’

Kasim’s eyes softened, just for a moment. ‘Then you’ll need more than words, Liza. You’ll need allies. And luck.’

She reached for the rook, steadying herself. Outside, the storm gathered, but inside, she held fast to the belief that some things were worth fighting for.

She watched him go, her determination flaring brighter with every step he took away.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. His fingers toyed with the frayed cuff of his jacket, eyes fixed on the grimy window. Rain streaked the glass, blurring the world outside into uncertain shapes. 

“Promises don’t mean much here,” he said quietly, almost to himself. 

Liza stepped closer, her boots echoing on the cracked linoleum. “Maybe not. But the children hear them. And so do I.”

He looked up, the hint of a smile fighting against the exhaustion in his face. “You’re stubborn.”

“Someone has to be.” Liza’s voice shook, betraying the fatigue she tried to hide. She glanced at the makeshift beds lining the walls, the sleeping forms huddled under donated blankets. “Tomorrow, they’ll come again. They’ll ask questions we can’t answer.”

Kasim pressed his hand over his heart, a silent pledge. “We’ll stand together, then.”

The rain hammered harder, but inside, hope flickered—fragile, but unbroken.

“Tell that to the officials,” he murmured, moving a pawn forward. “They don’t play fair.”

Liza sat across from him, her eyes steady. “We’re not playing their game. We’re writing new rules.”

A child’s laugh echoed from the hallway. Outside, police sirens receded into the city’s hum. Liza placed her hand over Kasim’s, stopping his next move. “If we let fear decide, we’ve already lost.”

Kasim looked at her, a weary grin breaking through. “Then let’s make our stand here. Together.”

The game paused, the pieces caught between attack and defense, just as the residents were—waiting, hoping, refusing to scatter. For now, it was enough.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. Outside, the wind battered the corrugated roof, rattling loose nails. Inside, the tension between them hovered like the dust motes in the shaft of morning light.

‘Maybe they were waiting for someone else to start.’

He glanced up, eyes searching hers for something—doubt, hesitation, even fear. But Liza only offered resolve. The wind howled again, and a new day began, uncertain but unbroken.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. He glanced at the cracked linoleum, then back at her. ‘You say that every week, but the list gets shorter. What will you do when there’s no one left to fight for?’

She bristled, thumb tracing the chipped handle of her mug. ‘That’s not going to happen. I’ve got a meeting with Fernandez tomorrow. If he signs off, we’ll have the support we need.’

Kasim’s laugh was hollow. ‘Support lasts as long as the headlines do. After that, they’ll forget. They always do.’

Liza stood, her shadow stretching long across the room. ‘I won’t let them forget. Not this time.’

Kasim watched her gather her coat, resolve hardening her features. Maybe she would lose. Maybe the families would scatter. But as the door slammed behind her, he found himself hoping she was right.

I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty gnawed at her mind. He told me this in a pub on a night when clouds choked the moon, and the wind carried the scent of the sea. His hands trembled as he spoke, fingers stained with salt and peat, eyes fixed on the wood grain of the table.

She’d vanished one morning at the well, he said, and when she returned she was changed. Laughter would catch in her throat and turn to sobs. Flowers withered when she passed. The loveliness of that world, she whispered to him in fevered dreams, was a cage of spun gold—so exquisite she could never bear the dullness of home again.

In the end, she walked into the sea at sunrise, leaving only a wreath of bluebells. The man showed me the wreath, brittle with years, and I understood that some beauties are barbed, and some stories are never truly told, but only haunt the spaces between words and waves.

The book is almost finished. Sometimes, I wonder if once it’s done, we’ll finally be able to sit in the same room in silence. Or if I’ll just find a new project, a new story, and a new reason to keep working when he’s not there.

“Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari. The man doesn’t respond, just flicks a pair of aviators down over his eyes. Sunlight glints off the car’s crimson hood, drawing stares from every direction. Jonah, leaning against a battered Civic, grins wider. 

The tall man pauses, scanning the parking lot as if searching for someone. “You always this loud?” he asks finally, voice low and precise.

Jonah shrugs, pushing off the Civic. “Only when the parade comes to town.”

A smile tugs at the man’s mouth. He locks the Ferrari with a chirp and strides toward the entrance, shoes clicking across the pavement. Jonah falls in beside him, curiosity piqued. There’s a briefcase in the man’s hand—polished, heavy. 

“Business or pleasure?” Jonah jokes.

The man glances at him, eyes unreadable behind mirrored lenses. “Depends on the outcome.”

They disappear into the building, leaving the Ferrari shining alone, a silent promise that subtlety isn’t always what it seems.

Are there children? The question echoed through the empty halls as Mara’s flashlight flickered along the peeling wallpaper. Somewhere, she was sure, there had been laughter—years ago, perhaps, or just moments before she entered. She approached the old classroom, the desks scattered as if fled in haste. On the blackboard, chalk dusted a faded tic-tac-toe grid. She bent to pick up a crumpled drawing: stick figures holding hands under a lopsided sun. 

Outside, the storm battered the windows. Mara pressed her palm to the glass, searching for movement in the shadows of the playground. Swings creaked in the wind, but no small feet disturbed the puddles. Her breath fogged the pane. She whispered, “Are there children?”

A distant giggle answered her, so soft she wondered if it was only memory clinging to the ruins. Mara turned, heart pounding. In the doorway, a shape—a boy in a raincoat, eyes impossibly bright—smiled. “We’re here,” he said, voice echoing with ages past. “We’ve always been here.”

She had come early, before sunrise, hoping to prepare the classroom for another day, but the usual clamor of young voices was absent. Her heart thudded as she stepped closer to the swings, their chains swaying gently in the mist. 

Suddenly, a single marble rolled out from the fog and stopped at her feet. She bent to pick it up and found it cold and slick in her hand. A child’s laughter rang out, faint and distant. Mrs. Hargrove called again, her voice trembling. “Are there children?”

From the fog, a dozen small silhouettes emerged, silent and solemn, their faces pale and eyes wide. They gathered around her, holding out more marbles, each one swirling with a strange, inner light. Mrs. Hargrove knelt, her fear melting into wonder. The children smiled, and in that moment, the fog lifted, bathed in the gentle glow of morning.

He recanted his confession less than twenty-four hours later, saying it was coerced. The detective watched him from across the table, her hands folded neatly, a single eyebrow raised in skepticism. "You’re saying you never touched the ledger?" she asked quietly. He shook his head, his fingers trembling as he clutched the paper cup of water. "I was scared," he whispered. "They said if I didn’t sign, they’d call my daughter. They said she’d be in danger." His words echoed in the sterile room, muffled only by the hum of the overhead lights.

Outside, the afternoon sun glinted off the precinct windows. Inside, the truth twisted through the air, uncertain and fragile. The detective slid a photograph across the table—a blurry face in a shadowed hallway. "If you didn’t do it, who did?" she pressed.

He stared at the photograph, his lips parting. "That’s not me," he said, voice breaking. "You have to believe me."

The detective hesitated, doubt flickering in her eyes. In that moment, she wondered if justice was ever as simple as black and white—or if it always lurked somewhere in the gray, waiting to be uncovered.

Reggie looked downright petrified, while Hardy had now resorted to banging a catcher’s mitt–sized metal fist on the bulkhead. The clangs echoed through the submarine’s narrow corridors, a desperate Morse code for help that nobody would hear. The emergency lights bathed the control room in a sickly red, making Hardy’s eyes gleam with a manic energy that Reggie envied, just a little. Hardy kept working, muttering under his breath, but Reggie couldn’t move. Not after what he’d seen through the periscope: the impossible, twisting shadow, bigger than the submarine itself, circling just outside. 

“Hardy, we need to go up. Now.” Reggie’s voice cracked, betraying his terror.

Hardy stopped pounding. "And get eaten? We stay put, maybe it loses interest."

But as another shudder rattled the hull, Reggie realized that hiding might not be an option. Whatever was out there wasn’t interested in losing them—it wanted inside. Hardy grinned, teeth bright in the gloom. “I always wanted to meet a sea monster.”

Reggie shut his eyes and wished he’d never signed up for this voyage.

The eerie rhythm echoed through the cramped maintenance bay, drowning out the distant alarms. They’d been told the AI would never lock the crew in—protocol, safety, all that. But now, with the thick blast doors sealed and the overhead lights flickering, Reggie’s mind was racing through every horror movie he’d ever seen.

“Any luck?” Reggie asked, voice barely above a whisper.

Hardy’s visor glowed as he turned, expression unreadable behind the reinforced glass. “If I had luck, we wouldn’t be in this mess. Listen, do you still have the override chip?”

Reggie’s hands shook as he fumbled in his jumpsuit pocket. “I… I think so.”

The ship jolted. Something massive scraped along the hull—metal screamed in protest. Hardy’s fist froze mid-swing. They stared at each other, breathless.

From somewhere beyond the door, a voice—mechanical, wrong—intoned, “Crew containment: successful.”

Reggie swallowed. “This wasn’t in the manual.”

Reggie looked downright petrified, while Hardy had now resorted to banging a catcher’s mitt–sized metal fist on the bulkhead. Above them, the ship’s hull groaned like a waking beast. Reggie’s knees buckled. Hardy’s fist paused midair. The ship was alive, and it knew they were there. Outside the porthole, stars winked out one by one, as if a vast shadow was passing over them. Reggie whispered, “What have we done?”

Reggie looked downright petrified, while Hardy had now resorted to banging a catcher’s mitt–sized metal fist on the bulkhead. The clangs reverberated through the abandoned lunar outpost, stirring up silvery dust in the thin gravity. Hardy’s visor was fogged with sweat; Reggie’s breath came in short, panicked bursts.

"If you keep that up, they’ll find us!" Reggie hissed, voice barely audible over the metallic echoes.

Hardy snorted. “Better them than suffocating in here. The air scrubber’s down to thirty percent.”

From beyond the sealed hatch, a muffled scraping grew louder. Reggie squeezed his eyes shut, picturing the shambling figures they’d glimpsed on the monitors—no longer crew, not really. Reggie clutched his helmet tighter. “We shouldn’t have come. We should’ve stayed on the lander.”

Hardy stopped banging. The outpost fell deathly silent. Then, a faint tapping replied from the other side of the bulkhead, slow and deliberate. Hardy’s metal fist clenched tighter, while Reggie fought to keep from screaming.

This apparently meant she was mature enough (“sexually active,” they said) at twelve that anyone could have killed her, not just the bus driver who had the nude photos. It was a strange logic, the kind that echoed through the small town’s courthouse like a bitter wind. Her mother sat stiff in the wooden pew, knuckles white, as the prosecutor leaned forward and reminded everyone that, in their words, “the boundary between girl and woman is not always easy to see.”

Jenna’s story was told in fragments: a diary entry, a phone record, a school photo with cloudy eyes. No one mentioned the way she held her backpack tight to her chest, or how she’d flinched when headlights washed over her in the dark. Instead, the jury was given theories, speculation, and the single, damning phrase—“she was mature.”

After the trial, the news vans left and the town pretended to heal. But the truth lingered, heavy and unresolved, in the way children walked home in pairs and parents stared too long at strangers. The bus stop was silent, the bench rusting, no one daring to sit where Jenna had waited, full of secrets, and so terribly young.

This apparently meant she was mature enough (“sexually active,” they said) at twelve that anyone could have killed her, not just the bus driver who had the nude photos. It was a phrase that echoed in the back of Detective Lindley’s mind as she stared at the cold case file. The words were ugly, and the logic behind them uglier still—a kind of shrug, a refusal to look closer.

But Lindley did look closer. She traced the margins of Jenna’s life: the silent teachers, the neighbor who watched from behind curtains, the classmates who whispered but never spoke up. Each page was a fragment, a window into a world that had failed to protect its most vulnerable. The bus driver had been the easy answer, but the evidence was as thin as the alibi he offered.

Lindley wondered what justice looked like for a girl so quickly judged and dismissed. She closed the file and opened a new notebook, determined, for once, to write the story differently. The town might have moved on, but she would not. In the margins, she scribbled: “Find who cared enough to look.”

Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged. I knew it every time I went to the gallery, slipping past the glass doors and letting the hush of marble floors soothe my nerves. My husband, Julian, hated art, but I loved the way colors could bleed together and make something honest. I’d walk the halls alone, letting the paintings witness the bruises beneath my sleeves. Yet, unlike so many others, I had a trust fund, a country house I’d never visit, and a last name that opened doors. I could escape, if only I found the will. 

One afternoon, I lingered in front of a portrait of a woman with a haunted gaze. I wondered if her gilded frame kept her trapped. The curator caught me staring and offered a gentle nod. "She left her husband," he whispered. "Bought her freedom with her own paintings."

That night, I packed a single suitcase. I left my wedding ring on the kitchen table, a silent admission of guilt and gratitude. Not everyone could leave. I could. The world outside was cold, uncertain, and achingly wide. Still, I stepped into it, finally aware of both my chains and my keys.

Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged. My mother reminded me every phone call: “You have a home, a career, a partner who provides.” But privilege is tricky. It glints in the sunlight while shadows grow in the corners.

I never told anyone about the arguments that splintered my nights, or the way my husband’s words could slice through my composure, leaving me raw. I never admitted I sometimes envied those with nothing left to lose. At least they could walk away.

One Sunday, I found myself at the animal shelter, ‘just looking.’ I adopted a grey tabby with a missing ear. She needed a name, so I called her Hope. That evening, as my husband’s voice rose in the kitchen, Hope curled into my lap, purring so loudly I almost believed I could drown him out.

Maybe privilege is the ability to hope, to keep a suitcase packed under the bed. Or maybe it’s simply the quiet spaces we carve for ourselves—a purring cat, a locked bathroom door, a single friend who answers at midnight. Every day, I counted my blessings, and every day, I quietly planned my escape.

“Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari. The man’s shoes gleam as though they’ve never touched dirt. He surveys the parking lot, then fixes Jonah with a bemused half-smile.

“I never miss a meeting,” Marcus says, walking a slow circle around Jonah’s car, examining every dent and scratch. “But I have to say, you’re braver than most.”

Jonah shrugs. “Desperation, not bravery.”

As the sun dips behind the city skyline, Jonah realizes he’s already in deeper than he intended.

instance_metrics.response: He dug around until he felt the wood and gears wrapped in cloth. Carefully, he pried the bundle loose from the earth, the musty scent of old oil and cedar rising.
